is a charming city on the edge of the Appalachian Mountains and near the Potomac River in NW
. It is the county seat of, and the largest city in,

. The city is perhaps best known for its outstanding outlet mall, which offers a huge variety of clothing among other things. It is named after Jonathan Hager, a German settler who founded the community in the mid-1700s. Hagerstown has an approximate population of 40,000 (metropolitan population of ~260,000) and is the fastest growing metro area in Maryland.
Hagerstown is only 80 minutes away from
. The main interstate highways running by the city are I-81 and I-70, each of which have multiple well-signed exits for Hagerstown.
), located 5 miles (8 km) outside of the city, is commercially serviced with flights to and from Orlando-Sanford International Airport and Washington-Dulles.  Alternatively, one can use
) all of which are within 60 miles (97 km) to 75 miles (121 km) driving distance of Hagerstown.

value: Renting cars or driving to Hagerstown is advised because only the downtown area is walkable. Walking downtown, however, is safe and charming.
For a taxi you could call Miller Cabs, Turner Vans, or hail Downtown Taxi! cabs on the streets in downtown.
County Commuter buses are effective and go to all points in the city.
View of the mountains from a Hagerstown suburb on a beautiful January day.

Aside from simply admiring the ubiquitous vistas of the Appalachian Mountains, you might also want to see:

value: content=Stroll through a beautifully traditional city park, with playgrounds for the kids, picnic areas, and a flock of ducks and geese to accompany you on your walk around the park's lake.
content=See the founder of Hagerstown's pre-Revolutionary War house.
name=Washington County Museum of Fine Arts
content=Symphony House that plays host to famous performers and all of the Maryland beauty pageants. Home to the Maryland Symphony Orchestra.
content=Theatre in restored Tusing Warehouse that houses the Potomac Playmakers community theatre group. Also includes 30,000 square feet of banquet and conference center space.

The city is a focal point for mountain bikers, fishermen, canoeists and hunters interested in the plentiful outdoor recreational opportunities in the area. The Appalachian Trail and the C&O Canal Towpath are close by.

content=The Valley Mall is one of two indoor malls in the Hagerstown Metropolitan area (the other is the Martinsburg Mall). There is over 900,000 square feet of retail space. The anchors are Macy's, The Bon-Ton, JCPenney, Sears, Regal Cinemas 16, Toys 'R' Us, and Old Navy.
content=Greek and American cuisine. Drive-thru and pick-up services also available.
content=Has typical American cuisine. Good for a budget.
content=Gourmet Deli sandwiches, salads, homemade soups, and homemade desserts. Great place for a quick, light, inexpensive lunch.
directions=Located at the Review & Herald Publishing Association.

content=Enjoy a healthy vegetarian meal with choices for a vegan or non-vegan diet. After lunch, take a tour of the press and see beautiful original artwork displayed. A bookstore is also available for browsing and purchasing.
directions=In the Arts and Entertainment District across from Maryland Theatre
content=Bulls & Bears presents Downtown Hagerstown with a unique experience featuring American cuisine in a New York style atmosphere. Attached is Traders on Potomac convenience store.

content=Dining at the Plaza Hotel will be a memorable experience. Attached to the Ramada Plaza Hotel, the Fireside Restaurant offers a full menu of steaks, seafood, and other American specialties in an upscale surrounding.

content=Has a casual, friendly Irish pub atmosphere and features an excellent selection of draft beers from regional craft brewers and an impressive bottled beer selection that includes intelligently selected Belgian, English, and German classics. The only place in Hagerstown that rivals the beer quality is the bar at Schmankerl Stube.

, Located on Summit Avenue in Downtown. One of Hagerstown's historical landmarks, this ten story hotel has a lot of history and used to be one of the tallest buildings in Hagerstown along with the twelve story Alexander House Tower in Public Square, until the Potomac Towers Apartments (15 stories) were built. Convenience store located inside facility.

content=On-site cocktail lounge, meeting and banquet facilities, and heated indoor pool. Free wifi and HBO. Provides extended stay amenities and services. Walking distance to restaurants. Within 2 miles of Hagerstown attractions.
